thread.text: Both are good phones but depends on what you need.

I had a hard time with this myself. I basically want the best camera you can get in and Android phone, but also want a UI that is close to stock. I've compared the S8, Pixel and OP5. I've looked heavily into professional reviews that focus on the camera and the OP5 comes out very close to the S8, which beats the Pixel. For the difference in cost, and the very nice close to stock Android UI, I'll take the OP5 all day every day.
If you are a budget buyer then one plus 5 is best for you but if you can afford s8 it is more better in display and camera but the performance is same

At the price that you mentioned the S8 is an extremely attractive offer. At any other price I have seen I believe that the OnePlus5 is more attractive. So like any other deal it just depends on what pricing you are able to get!

title: How good truly is the One Plus 5?

thread.text: Many people say the one plus 5 is a great smartphone, and it seems like it. But is it actually a great phone that can compete with flagships like the galaxy S8 or is it only good relative to its low price?

I would say it can compete with the S8 in lots of aspects (software, processor, RAM, etc), and it can not in some very few others (camera, for instance). It all really depends on what you want from the phone.
Its an awesome phone especially for gaming it fully competes with flagships ,great in multitasking and display is great.it is best for budget buyers .If you are heavy user than this is for you

I think it clearly is an outstanding phone. Having said that it competes with top of the line cell phones at a much lower price point. So clearly it is going to be a few features and a few top shelf components short of the most expensive phones. What it accomplishes despite that is fairly remarkable.

replies.text:
I completely agree with this. Very nice phone, with some let downs but for the price it can really be beat.

title: Some users are reporting that the OnePlus 5 reboots when making a 911 call

thread.text:

Some users on Reddit are claiming that the OnePlus 5 may reboot when dialing an emergency number such as 911. https://www.reddit.com/r/oneplus/com...sterday_saw_a/

Some users are affected while others are not. Expect a full-on statement soon.

thread.text: I think that 8 gb is too overkill for a smartphone. The new version of android is optimized very well and it runs smooth even on 4GB of memory, but at the end its our choice which variant to buy. Buying a 8 GB variant will ensure you that you will receive all the future update without any hassle and you need not to worry about your getting slow due to new update because your phome will be having enough memory.
I think that for $60 more the 8 gb are worth it considering the speed
Go for the highest storage & ram as it does fill up very quickly with so many programs and data

If you've decided you want the 8/128 version, and have the cash, I'd wait for that rather than settling (#neversettle lol).
To paraphrase Shigeru Miyamoto, a delayed phone may eventually be great, but a rushed phone will be forever disappointing.
if you have the cash, go for the best version you can get. it'll end up lasting the longest and would have most resale value
It's all comes down to your internal storage requirements as this phone doesn't have external storage option. Is 64 GB memory good for you, if yes, go for 6gb one, if no, go for 8 gb one.
Is there any reference between the 6/8gb besides the memory size? For example battery life or performance?

It all depends on your end-purpose. You see, a 3GB Ram performs as good as a 6GB phone, well, at least in terms of running apps smoothly. A 6GB One Plus 5 is good enough, but spending an extra $60 for a whopping 8GB isn't a bad deal anyways. Over the last few years, Android manufacturers have been boasting about RAM, and ot be honest, RAM is far more important than storage. Storage can be improved by adding an SD card, or backing up your data to the cloud using Dropbox or Google Drive, but with an 8GB RAM and 128 GB storage option, I hardly doubt anyone's data is going to fill up One Plus 5's capacity. Nevertheless, go for an 8GB version.

6gb or 8gb ? Here the speed in 8gb OP5 is quite negligible comparing 6gb OP5. Here wat matters is the storage options u get. For 6gb u get 64gb storage , whereas for 8gb u get 128gb storage. If u don't mind 64 gjg storage ur good to go ! If u really u need more storage the 8gb / 128gb is worth the upgrade.
8gb is the best option.

Not for the RAM, but for the storage.
Having 128GB of ultrafast storage for not a heap more is a no-brainer IMO.

title: Most of the mobiles are getting heat while they are charging or using 4G network. what about OP5

replies.text: Some older phones actually do. Not the OP3 I have used though.

It's pretty common with phones that use Qualcomm quick charge, because it kind of sucks as a charging technique...
To answer the OP,, all phones will warm up a little when they're charged, but the Oneplus 3,3T and 5 that use dash charge as well as things like the pixel that use USB-PD will generally stay cooler than something using a higher voltage solution like quick charge.

thread.text:
OnePlus has its proprietary Dash Charge which moves the power management, and therefore the heat into the charger instead of being managed in the phone by the Qualcomm SoC.
That explains why it is less prone to generating extra heat.
Interesting the mention of USB-PD in at least two threads on this subject, something I admittedly am not familiar with.
Will look it up though.
Given the standardisation in many areas, why is this one not being implemented more widely.

The only other feature that doesn't work is the WiFi calling, but most ppl I know that have turned this feature off anyway since it causes calls to drop when switching between WiFi and Cell service. Voicemail and such works since it uses Google Voice and the app can be installed for that.

Their customer service is one of the best that I have ever had with any company.

title: OnePlus 5 Initial impressions- I'm on the fence

thread.text:
My OP5 8gb/128 model finally arrived yesterday (long story) and I had the chance to set it up and have a play last night. My initial impressions are mixed tbh hut here is what I think so far.
- It's super quick, greased lightning.
- Fingerprint sensor. On the front and very fast. Big thumbs up for that!
- Vanilla android is nice although it will strangely take some adjustments.  
- Does not feel as nice in the hand as I expected. Actually not that comfortable to hold tbh
- Screen is very nice although it feels more cramped than I was expecting due to the drop in res. vs my S8. Probably need to dive into nova and have a play with icon sizes etc
- Build quality feels ok, it does feel very light though. Not sure if I consider this a good or bad thing yet.
- wifi performance is TERRIBLE It took ages to install all my apps from google play as it it kept popping up a disconnected error. After they finally installed wifi feels noticeably slower than other recent phones I have used.
I have left it at home today as I am undecided if I am going to return it or not so it is back in the box ,today while I ponder......
Bummer, I know several updates were released this week - if performance is that bad I'd return it.
WiFi on mine is actually pretty great. Hitting almost 400mbps on the speedtest app on WiFi. Initial setup of apps was a bit slow, but then it was over 100 apps, so i'll cut it some slack.
I turned off "Smart WI-FI Switcher" and have not had any problems since. Have not tried un-switching with latest update although.

For WiFi issues, did you install the latest 4.5.3 update? That is supposed to fix the update.
Screen display - Yes, it's nowhere comparable to the S8 or G6 or the U11 but but certainly usable on a daily basis.
I quite like the build and love to hold due to its curved design on the sides

Dear Oneplus

I really loved a lot of things about the OP3T but I was paying off my last contract. I became contract free and am now in the world of unlocked phone and I just haven't been that interested in the OP5. For starters I don't trust the company, the camera is not what I was hoping for. I wanted a wide angle lense. Yeah, the rest of the specs are good but it's just not unique. The OP3T & OP3T had a unique recognizable look. The OP5 just doesn't look special to me. I like my phone to stand out and not blend with the isheep and gsheep. I think I'm going to get the U11. That thing is just sexy and I trust HTC to build a quality device and support it. I'm done with Samsung and all their baggage, I like the G6 but idk, it's just not exciting.
If the OP5 was under $400 I think it would be a more serious contender for me but so close in price to the U11, that kind of seals the deal for me.

thought I'll share my impression of the phone too after using it for a while. It's a decent phone with some clear advantage over its competitors like the performance, and the software experience (a bit subjective). Battery life is decent too. But to me it's very much the same formula as the OnePlus 3, which doesn't work quite as well this year for a few reasons. 
First the price is higher than before. Then the other flagship devices in the market are mostly pretty good this year, so it makes the compromises on the OP5 a little less tolerable too. Like the lack of water resistance, and the camera is no where near what OnePlus hyped it up to be. And of course at this point, prices of some other flagship devices are coming down in price (at least where I live). So a 6GB OP5 costs around the same as the LG G6, and only around 150USD cheaper than the Galaxy S8. Oh, and people are understandably a bit concerned about the update situation too looking at the OnePlus 2.
It's probably still worth it just for the performance and software experience in my opinion, but it's not as great a value compared to say the OP3 was back then.

I tried the OnePlus 5 earlier.
Quite honestly, it's a good phone, especially if you value sheer performance. Make no mistake, this thing is FAST. It's pretty hard to get this thing to cough up. 
It's not all roses, though. 1080p is fine for daily use but the display wasn't all that bright and I can actually see some slight pixelation even without overly squinting, possibly due to the PenTile submatrix. It won't bother most but it's something to note. The camera is also good but not to the degree it was hyped. In most conditions, it will deliver a solid photo but I wouldn't recommend using the zoom lens in anything other than good lighting as the smaller pixels and smaller aperture lead to more noise and as a result, heavier NR.
$540 is actually not a bad price at all for the specs you get, but that also means it's getting some competition from some actual flagships. Not all of them can touch the OnePlus for sheer speed, but some, like the G6, offers a more flexible camera while others provides more features.
It's your call on what you prefer.
I'm pretty happy with my OP5. My biggest gripe is the camera. Obviously I don't expect it to go toe to toe with the 900 dollar flagship, but it's missed too many shots for me.

Wow...after reading this thread its pretty obvious ill be keeping my G6 instead of trading it for the OP5. The only thing I don't like about my G6 is the rear placement of the home button and the lag that i get once in a while, but then I remember that I got the phone for 50% off through AT&T so I paid around $320 for it. Well worth the flaws.

If I use the same picture, you can't tell the difference. Or you have to come so close to the display that 1) you'll look stupid, and 2) you'll see only a part of the picture, and you'll look stupid.

I'm having issues holding the 5ghz band even when I manually set it to only use the 5ghz . It drops and use the 2.4ghz band and later in the day will go back to 5ghz some how. I thought 4.5.5 fixed this but apparently not. Any suggestions thanks

How far away from the router are you? Are there any obstructions like walls, people, furniture ect between you and the router? 
The 5ghz frequency while faster than the 'standard' 2.4ghz. It's got a shorter range and gets 'cut off' by various things more easily. 😃 
So that could be why it's dropping and switching. (not saying it is though)

Can u elaborate ?
As far as I know the 4.5.5 solves all minor issues! 5ghz is obvious faster then the 2.4 ghz

Aside from quality issues with the internal antenna and wireless chip inside your device differences between 2.4GHz and 5GHz are going to be determined by your wireless router so update or not you should focus more on your router. Placement is often an issue so as an example if you have your wireless router tucked under a desk in a corner office, moving on top of a cabinet in a more central location can help expand the effective range of the wireless signals emitted by your router. If your router has external antennas rearranging them will shape your effective range too.
Try installing this Wifi Analyzer app from the Play Store onto your phone, and then do a walk-through of your home so you can get a good idea on where there are weak spots as far as 5GHz weak spots:https://play.google.com/store/apps/d...analyzer&hl=en

i am within 1 feet of the router, so the same room in other words. every other device i have owned has help onto the 5ghz band except for this phone. i know it is not router related. guys i know the difference between the two bands, it is a problem of the phone holding that band and not switching itself to another. i want it to stay on 5ghz and it will not do that.
Unless you need 2.4GHz for specific devices why not just set your router with a 5GHz-only network. What model router do you have?
My printer has to use 2.4 so I made the 2.4 and the 5ghz the same name in case I also am out of distance for the 5ghz

title: Pixel XL or unlocked s8 or one plus 5?

thread.text: I’ve been using and loving my Pixel XL since it came out. I got the bug and bought an unlocked s8 on swappa. Now I bought a OnePlus 5 but haven’t turned it on yet. I installed nova launcher on the s8 but haven’t really tried it. So do I give the one plus 5 a try or are the other two better

Always a tough decision. I think the all round best device would be the Galaxy S8. 😃 The OnePlus 5 is definitely awesome but does lack in certain areas like not having IOS for the camera. I would even be happy keeping the Pixel XL. So my vote would be keep the S8.
Why not just try OP5 and if you don't like it, you can return it.

Two big things that will be key in your decision making: Screen Display and Camera.
You will have to test it out for yourself as you already have the OnePlus 5 to see how far you like it. Performance wise, you will find all those devices you have are really good, especially OP5 and S8 with SD835 processor.

How hard is it to return if I don’t 
Ike it.
Since you have all three of them, I DEMAND that you keep us informed of your decision, which will be a tough one
I will but I’m betting on keeping the Pixel XL

I have the S8+ and just got the OnePlus 5. I used the OnePlus for the last few days and I've switched back to the S8+ for a few reasons. The camera is not nearly as good on the OnePlus but it is still ok. Problem is the camera on the S8+ is really really good. Also the screen on the OnePlus is a little dim for my liking. OnePlus is fast as hell though! S8+ is really fast too. Both are good phones but the S8+ in my opinion is the better choice.

I had the same three phones (Pixel XL, S8+ and OP 5). Down to two now - Pixel XL & OP 5 and am leaning towards keeping the Pixel XL. The S8+ was a good phone, but it had some lag and found that I had to keep the resolution down to 1080 so I could get the battery life to last all day. I also hated the position of the fingerprint sensor on that phone. 
I find the OP 5's battery will not last all day and prefer the images coming out of the Pixel XL, so will stay with the Pixel XL. I do miss the waterproofing of the S8+ especially given Vancouver's constant rainy weather.

I bought an s8 unlocked rather than the s8+ figuring that it had about the same size screen as the other two. I like the form factor, but for some reason the screen feels smaller than the other two, even though it's not. I'm not sure what I'll keep at this point. Putting Nova launcher on the s8 makes it feel a little more like a pixel, but it still looks touch wiz like to me so I'll see.
S8 is the best phone around at the moment. OnePlus is a good phone but with quite a few compromises, that can be mitigated for extra $60-$120.
Pixel XL is still the best decide on the market, but s8 is also really awesome and it's cheaper with sales. OnePlus 5 seems to be a pretty big mess.

Right now I have no intentions of getting rid of the S8+ but will possibly sale the Pixel.

Pixel is the only recent Android flagship device where software and security are at the forefront and where privacy and security are taken seriously. I strongly prefer the metal body over the glass body. Camera is marginally better on the Pixel XL than the S8, though each is strong at their own things. 
So to my assessment the Pixel XL wins over the S8 on build materials, software, security, commitment to updates, camera, charging technology, design, lack of bloatware and OEM support. 
The S8+ then wins on display accuracy and on newer SoC. 
They're tied for all intents and purposes for my usage on water resistance, audio, battery capacity (<1.5% difference), build quality and network support.

title: migrate Nexus 5 to OnePlus 5 - decent FAQ?

thread.text:
Greetings -
My OnePlus 5 (Oxygen/Nougat) should arrive shortly to replace my ailing Nexus 5 (Marshmallow).
I've attempted to do my due diligence and research the transfer, but I'm left confused by articles that refer to slightly different processes/UIs.
Is NFC/Touch & Go the new paradigm? Is it really as simple as turning on both, enabling NFC and having the OnePlus pull in the apps & data? Any additional paid app considerations?
I'd welcome a good step by step FAQ (or, if I must, a video) that explains the process. Bottom line, I'd like to get as complete a migration as I can of apps & data, without putting my entire life on the cloud (any more than I already do). So, if it's *not* the NFC approach, a PC-based solution would be preferable to cloud-based.
Thanks kindly,
- Richard

The NFC setup thing is good, but it won't get everything.
You'll still have apps you'll need to setup manually, and you'll have to manually copy across any user data (pics, videos, downloaded files etc) also if you use a custom launcher you should back it up and transfer the backup.

I also came from a Nexus 5 to OP5 the NFC transfer although sounds like a good concept did not work for me as described. I still had to load all apps from another phone I had used as it would not pick up these from the Nexus 5 backup or through NFC.

I moved from an HTC 10. Tried the NFC thing. It essentially just told the OP5 what my google account was and then the OP5 proceeded to download all my apps from the play store. Google linked accounts required no further sign in, but did have to re-sign in to almost everything else (banks, dropbox, etc). One or 2 moved over the login credentials, but I forget which ones they were.
Had to manually move over pics, songs, vids, etc. Thankfully, I'd kept my old SD card adapter so I took that out of the 10 and plugged in straight to my laptop and moved over USB. Gotta admit, that was the fastest data transfer I've seen on a phone. About 25GB of data in 10-15 minutes (not 10% sure since I went to make dinner after I started the transfer).
The one annoyance was moving text messages over. Had to get an app (SMS Backup & Restore) to my about 45K text messages over. Not sure why That's not part of what Google allows to be backed up when switching phones.

Is anyone having issues with apps that use data? More specifically im having issues getting apps like tunein radio and pokemon go to work. I have full LTE service but the apps will not load up. Upon connecting to wifi they load up immediately. Apps like twitter and facebook do not seem to have any issues refreshing, but for whatever reason these apps fail to load.

I use TMobile in my OP5 and have had no issues so far. I even use dual SIM and have set one exclusively for data while the other SIM for voice and text. 
I have not tried those specific apps but Google Play Music streaming, browsing web all works fine in LTE.

replies.text: Thanks for the reply. I also am not having issues on most of my apps but I do see it with a few that I use often. I was already on the fence about keeping the device because for the cost its not giving me what I would get for a few bucks more from a u11. I had a short leash with the OP5 and this problem just seals the deal and ive already requested an RMA to send it back.

I feel like we're talking about several different things. 
Review units: It is very common for OEMs to provide review units to credible tech blogs and trusted reviewers so that the phone can be reviewed. This can happen before and after a device's release. In that exchange, there is no expectation of false praise or any other sort of bias based on the device being received as a review unit. It's not uncommon for review units to be returned to the OEM or given out as a contest, etc. 
Running contests: It's also very common for OEM's to provide devices to the same organizations in order to run contests. That's a win-win scenario, as the OEM gets in the news and the organization gets visits, members, subscribers, etc. That also does not come along with any strings attached, such as positive reviews.
So to be clear on what I'm asking you for - because you seem to be implying that sites like AC, AP, AA, CNET, TheVerge, etc, etc or reviewers like MKBHD, etc. are providing false information to consumers in exchange for compensation - is exactly who is being corrupted and in what form does this corruption take.

thread.text: Nope. Just says label created

Super Saf's comparison of the S8 and OnePlus 5 is very good in my view. He uses exactly the same tests each time and the same format. You can see for yourself the photos and videos and decide which you think is better. My conclusion from his review is that the cameras for the most part are both good, with the S8 having a slight edge for low light. Video at 4K is a very clear win for Samsung, but at 1080P/HD it's a win for the OP5 or a close tie. 
Daylight shots are pretty much on par but some people will prefer one over the other.
Some of the OP5's weaknesses are made up for by having the zoom if you feel that's useful.
For me, I've got an S8+, and bought the OnePlus 5. I know what I use my phone camera for. I do use video a lot, but 1080P is more than sufficient for me. I do very little low light photography and the OnePlus is very good at that even if not as good as the S8+. 
I love the optical zoom. I loved it on the iPhone 7 Plus I had for a few months. Overall, I think the camera will be more than good enough for me, and way better than the OP3t, and I am convinced it will improve with a software update very quickly anyway since OnePlus listens to the market and reviewers and fixes what they can with software. That's why they did that with the 3t.
To me, the performance difference is worth switching to the OP 5. No lag ever would be great.

thread.text: I'm not a displayphile, so I'm glad to see the lower res screen stay. Maybe I'll notice a difference from the quad HD displays I've been using for 3 years, but I'll take that trade for better performance and battery life.

replies.text:
TBH, the current QHD OLEDs have negligible power consumption increases over a FHD OLED. I've used the newer phones with QHD OLED panels alongside others with FHD OLEDs and I never found the FHD one to have a significant increase in battery life. 
Same goes with performance as newer chipsets are in fact designed for these higher resolutions.
Back in 2014, we would say that the decision to stick with 1080p was justified as processors were still not capable of driving higher-resolutions without significant amounts of strain and displays running at a higher resolution needed more power, but we've come a ways since then. The cost to the user-experience of a higher-resolution display has mostly been ironed out at this point.

thread.text: I have good eyesight, and I couldn't possibly go back to 1080p.
It still has better PPI than Retina displays.

replies.text:
Not entirely.
Its effective resolution is actually similar to that on the regular iPhone 7, as mentioned by Anandtech on the OnePlus 3 review;
"When you consider the effective resolution of red and blue on the OnePlus 3, you're really dealing with a display that is roughly equivalent to the iPhone 6s in chroma resolution, except on a 5.5" display instead of a 4.7" one. The resolution for green is equivalent to a 1080p display, and subpixel rendering is what allows you to make the claim that it's still a 1080p display, but for everything except pure green your effective resolution is going to be lower. In addition to that, the uneven size and spacing of the subpixels, along with their diamond pattern, makes them less than optimal for rendering the latin alphabet which contains many vertical lines. This kind of screen door effect has long been noticed on PenTile displays, and for the most part the push for 1440p AMOLED panels has mitigated those complaints.On the OnePlus 3 it's pretty obvious that text is rendered less clearly than the iPhone 6s, which has a pixel density of only 326ppi, well below that of flagship Android devices. With the OnePlus One and OnePlus 2 for comparison it's completely obvious that the OnePlus 3 has a lower effective resolution, with text exhibiting distracting artifacts, and solid patterns that are red, blue, or white having a crosshatch pattern that simply isn't visible on OnePlus's older smartphones. I completely agreed with OnePlus's choice of 1080p on their past smartphones, but saying that there's no benefit to going higher on a PenTile AMOLED display is simply false, and there's no getting around the fact that the OnePlus 3 has a lower effective resolution than its predecessors. "
The OnePlus 5 uses a similar panel, albeit slightly improved in terms of calibration.
Exactly!

thread.text: but don't they say that the QHD of the Galaxy S8 uses more battery than FHD, they give the option to lower the screen to save some battery, so... ?

replies.text:
Actually, no.
You only see battery savings by going all the way down to 720p. The battery drain difference between the S8 in FHD and QHD is pretty much negligible.

thread.text:
Having a 1440p panel would obviously be a great addition and welcomed but for the average user (no VR), I think 1080p is perfect. 😃 Also, having a lower rez screen helps with battery life (might not be huge but still something) and I'm all for a longer lasting battery.
